thread.title: Charlie lets his horses run over Whitwell
thread.title_full: Charlie lets his horses run over Whitwell

title: Charlie lets his horses run over Whitwell
text:
Charlie lets his horses run over Whitwell Charlie lets his horses run over Whitwell 
Columbia Academy running back Logan "Blackjack" Neal (21) carries the ball during the game against Whitwell on Friday in Whitwell. (Photo by correspondent Rob Fleming) Charlie lets his horses run over Whitwell 
Columbia Academy cornerback Rush Lansdell (14) covers his man during the game against Whitwell on Friday in Whitwell. (Photo by correspondent Rob Fleming) Charlie lets his horses run over Whitwell 
Columbia Academy safety Taylor Thompson (1) pummels a Whitwell player during the game on Friday in Whitwell. (Photo by correspondent Rob Fleming) By CALEB ODOM codom@c-dh.net 
WHITWELL — Columbia Academy won its eighth straight game on Friday with a 41-24 victory over Whitwell. 
The Bulldogs (8-1) were out to prove that they were not just a one trick pony that could only pass the ball to senior standout receiver Taylor Thompson. 
Three rushing scores by three different players in the lopsided contest proved just that for a program that is preparing for a playoff run in just two weeks. 
Thompson closed out the game with a pair of scores while Thomas Garrison had a touchdown catch and another punt return for a touchdown. 
CA quarterback, Dylan Johnson, was slightly off of his usually flawless game, completing just 4 of 11 passes for 60 yards despite throwing for a pair of TDs. 
It would make little difference though as Whitwell lacked the discipline or ability to score points on the Bulldog starting defense. 
“There early offensively, I couldn’t get into a rhythm calling plays and that caused us to stall out a little bit,” CA head coach Charlie Lansdell said. 
Even though the Bulldog offense may have been somewhat out of sync at points, Columbia Academy was firmly in control. 
The foundation for CA in this game was the punishing Bulldog defense that was led by the crushing blows of Thompson. 
The senior safety was tattooing Whitwell ball carriers whenever the Tigers made it to his territory. 
CA linebacker, Billy Thurman, also joined in the fun of causing trouble for Whitwell’s anemic offense. 
His white uniform stained brown from the mud, Thurman collected five tackles and a sack just one week removed from being unable to play with a sore left shoulder. 
“Billy is a big part of our defense,” Lansdell said. “He does a really good job for us at linebacker and we were glad to have him back out there.” 
Thurman injured his left ankle in the second quarter of the Friday game, but was able to come back in the second half. 
“It’s maybe a high ankle sprain,” Thurman said. “It may just be a bruise.” 
Another Bulldog defender, who helped the team considerably, was the freshman starting cornerback, Rush Lansdell, who finished the game with four tackles. 
Even though Rush sustained a stinger on his right shoulder in the first half, the corner returned to stifle the Whitwell offense. 
“I try to be like some of the Alabama DBs, they fly around the football,” Rush said. “They are good in coverage. I kind of like to watch them, kind of represent them.” 
Columbia Academy’s most impressive drive of the game opened the first quarter when the Bulldogs ran the ball down Whitwell’s throat on six straight carries to paydirt. 
“That was planned,” Charlie Lansdell said “We wanted to come out and run the football a little bit tonight and show people that we are a balanced team. We can run the ball just as well as we can throw it.” 
A 10-yard power toss to the right by Garrison was followed by an 8-yard carry by Hudson Primm. 
With the ball at midfield, it was Logan Neal’s turn to gash the Tiger defense with his legs as the running back nicknamed, “Blackjack” gained 31 yards blasting to the left. 
“I tell you what, that’s an awesome sight. I love it man,” Neal said. “When you see that open as a running back, all you do is you shift another gear and try to get as much as you can.” 
Neal’s carry took CA down to the Tiger 19 when Garrison marched the pigskin another 12 yards to the seven. 
A 2-yard run up the gut by Primm got the Bulldogs near the end zone and Neal would do the rest for the 2-yard touchdown run. 
With 10:06 to play in the first quarter, Columbia Academy was already up 7-0 without attempting a pass. 
“It shows how lethal Thomas and Hudson are and it just really shows what we can do,” Neal said. “When we are on fire blocking and everybody is getting their blocks and doing their jobs, I don’t really think anybody is going to stop us.” 
The Bulldogs padded their lead at 14-0, with 5:34 to play in the opening quarter, when Johnson found Thompson for a 15-yard touchdown grab. 
CA showed more of its offensive balance when Primm pounded his way two yards for the team’s third touchdown of the game and a 21-0 score with 1:33 to play in the second quarter. 
“We’re such a dynamic team,” Primm said. “Every time we step on to the field, you never know what we are going to do.” 
Just before halftime, Whitwell punted the ball to Thompson who returned it 64 yards coming just a yard short of scoring a touchdown. 
With 17 seconds remaining in the second quarter, Thompson forced himself over the goal line on a wildcat play for the 1-yard score that made it 28-0, CA at the half. 
It was more of the same for the Bulldogs early in the third quarter as Garrison showed his speed on a 60-yard punt return for a touchdown. 
With the score already at 35-0 in favor of Columbia Academy, Mr. Everything made another electrifying play with the ball in his hands as Johnson connected with Garrison for a 23-yard scoring catch. 
Whitwell’s Jake Sartin would collect three rushing touchdowns against CA’s freshmen and JV defense, but it would be too little too late as the Bulldogs cruised 41-24 in the end.
